creator: mhd_medfa1
title: Geek Baby
description: This project uses homemade resistive touch sensors to trigger actions on a connected computer device. Touching different areas of the sensor interface results in different actions, such as playing a laughing baby sound, playing a sleep tune and hibernating the computer, or opening Facebook.
steps: Gather all the required materials, including wires, a breadboard, batteries (5V and 0.5-2V), 6.8MOhm resistors, LM358 ICs, 100nF capacitors, a Tiva C TM4C1294 (or Arduino), cloth, an avometer, cutter wires, medical adhesive tape, and makeup cotton.
Refer to the block diagram and project files available at the provided Google Drive link for detailed instructions.
Optionally, watch the video (in Arabic) for a demonstration of the project.

creator: mhd_medfa1
title: Geek Baby
materials_required: 5V battery and a 0.5-2V battery (or 9V battery with 7805 voltage regulator)
description: This project uses homemade resistive touch sensors to trigger actions on a connected computer. Touching different sensor locations will play a laughing baby sound, activate sleep mode, or open Facebook.
steps: Gather the required materials, including wires, breadboard, batteries, resistors, ICs, capacitors, Tiva C (or Arduino), cloth, avometer, cutter wires, medical adhesive tape, and makeup cotton.
Refer to the block diagram and project files available at the provided Google Drive link.
A video demonstration in Arabic is available (implied).

creator: mhd_medfa1
title: Geek Baby
materials_required: 5V battery and 0.5-2V battery (or 9V battery with 7805 voltage regulator)
description: This project utilizes homemade resistive touch sensors to trigger specific actions on a connected computer device. Touching different areas of the screen will result in various functions such as playing a laughing baby sound, playing a sleep tune and hibernating the computer, or opening Facebook.
steps: Gather all the necessary materials, including wires, a breadboard, batteries, resistors, ICs, capacitors, a microcontroller (Tiva C or Arduino), cloth, an avometer, wire cutters, medical adhesive tape, and makeup cotton.
Build the circuit for the homemade resistive touch sensors using the LM358 ICs and resistors.
Connect the sensors to the microcontroller.
Program the microcontroller to detect touches on the sensors and trigger the corresponding actions (playing sounds, hibernating, opening Facebook).
Use a cloth to cover the wires and make the project visually appealing.
Refer to the block diagram and project files for detailed instructions: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B4QHt7IBKP-9bTVwTVE5am9NaUk/view?usp=sharing
